title-group.article-title: From “Publish or Perish” to “Grant or Perish”
title-group.subtitle: Examining Grantsmanship in Communication and the Pressures on Communication Faculty to Procure External Funding for Research

article-meta.aff: 1University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, USA

author-notes.corresp: George Musambira, Nicholson School of Communication, University of Central Florida, PO Box 161344, 4000 Central Florida Blvd., Orlando, FL 32816-1344, USA Email: George.Musambira@ucf.edu

abstract.p: Although communication program faculty have traditionally not enjoyed large grants for research, administrators are pressuring them to garner external funding. This article examines the success rate of securing external funding that communication administrators reported for their units. Results show that while the pressure has increased on most communication programs, the success rate for getting those grants has not. In addition, support for seeking grants is not growing with the pressure, and there seems to be little difference in support between high research-oriented programs and those in lower Carnegie classifications, with the exception of help from graduate students.

body.p: The economic downturn since the early 2000s has not made it any easier for faculty in communication and other disciplines who are facing mounting pressure to secure external dollars for their programs. Although some faculty in all academic disciplines experience pressure to generate external revenue, those in disciplines such as communication that are located in the humanities or social sciences face an even steeper incline.1 The situation is less dire in the hard and applied sciences such as physics and engineering, respectively, but it is also quickly changing toward greater competition.2 This study examines the conditions within which faculty in the disciplines of journalism and mass communication (J/MC) and human communication (HC) are pressured to generate external research revenue for their departments and institutions. As “get grants or perish”3 is fast becoming the modus operandi of the academy in these disciplines, it is imperative to research the norms surrounding faculty external grants activities. This study investigates organizational factors and characteristics that are associated with external grant-seeking activity and acquisition, by addressing gaps in the literature as explained later.

sec.title: Literature Review
sec.p: Scholarship on university faculty research and funding of that research does exist, but it is not abundant. What follows is a review of that limited research. Payne and Siow suggest that from 1972 to 1998 increased funding from the federal government did result in greater research output, although those researchers did not measure quality of output.4 Increased incentives for garnering external funds in European and Australian universities did not boost faculty productivity. In fact, the incentives may actually create more dysfunction at universities, as the efforts become more focused on getting grants rather than producing scholarship and researchers focus more on topics for which they can obtain funding rather than the pressing questions in their discipline or what interests them individually.5

Generally, the scholarship on faculty productivity in J/MC and HC is fractured among studies on gender equality in productivity,6 and among studies on research articles and citations.7 Much less emphasized are research grants as indicators of faculty productivity. This is because funded research and published articles may be isomorphic to a great extent.8 However, pressure on faculty to engage in external grant activities has been mounting because administrators feel dissatisfied with faculty performance in this area.9 This pressure may be the result of declining monetary support of public universities by various stakeholders,10 including “public budget cuts [that] have pushed institutions to pressure their faculty to do more funded research.”11 Federal funding for research in mass communication has dropped precipitously,12 and yet “[t]he value of college endowments declined by an average of 23 percent from 2008 to 2009, socked by the one-two punch of record investment losses and a precipitous drop in giving.”13

In the mid-1980s, Schweitzer examined faculty productivity in J/MC programs,14 starting with a call for more industry-related research from the academy. In follow-up work,15 he found that schools with doctoral programs published more than nondoctoral programs, and while intrinsic motivations (personal satisfaction) were the most influential predictor of research success among faculty, a supportive administration was important in facilitating research activity among faculty.16 He concluded that while expectations of research productivity may vary among institutions,17 administrators who created cultures that enhanced and supported research through funding and rewards (travel money, etc.) were more likely to have faculty with higher research productivity.18 Nearly fifteen years later, Beard in one study and Morton and Beard in another study examined communication research productivity including two factors that earlier research did not address: external funding or grants and (Carnegie) institution classification.19 Beard surveyed administrators of J/MC programs and found that a slight majority of programs (51.9 percent) had succeeded in securing at least one externally funded grant in the year prior to the study.20 The mean rate for programs achieving an externally funded grant was 1.13. Programs located on doctoral campuses were more likely (93.5) to engage in external grant activities than programs housed in either master’s (60 percent) or baccalaureate institutions (50 percent). While programs with established graduate programs, especially ones with doctoral programs, were more likely to report higher levels of external grant activity and acquisition than those that didn’t have graduate programs, it wasn’t the case that differences were significant in this regard between doctoral programs and master’s, or between master’s and bachelor’s. Moreover, when compared to master’s or baccalaureate schools, doctoral programs were perceived by faculty to encourage more networking or collaboration among members with similar grant or research interests and to provide greater opportunities for such networking.

Morton and Beard analyzed the content of 223 mass communication educators’ vitae based on a modified version of the 1994 Carnegie classification system, limiting the analysis to three of the five levels: Research I and II, Doctoral I and II, and Master’s I and II. In terms of the dollar value of external grants, there were very few differences among programs in the different classifications.21

sec.title: Department size as a predictor of external grant productivity
sec.p: Although little research has examined the relationship between external grant acquisition and faculty size, the literature on scholarly productivity in general is instructive. Also, Bland et al. suggest that faculty size is important because a critical mass is necessary for a unit to accomplish its research goals amid other professional obligations in the academy.22 Stephen found that “the number of publishing faculty in a [communication] program is strongly related to positive perceptions of faculty quality.”23 In addition, once the number of nonpublishing faculty was controlled for, the correlation between number of faculty in the communication unit and the number of publications associated with the unit was high. These findings are consistent with earlier work concerning a different discipline,24 and with other research on more than 3,600 research–doctoral programs in the United States that found that the strongest predictors of faculty research productivity include the size of program and number of faculty who publish articles in peer-reviewed journals.25 Bland et al. also found that highly productive departments included “a large portion of the faculty [who] were grant-getters.”26

sec.title: Institutional/unit culture and external grant productivity
sec.p: Another relevant line of research concerns organizational culture. Bland et al.’s synthesis of studies on faculty research productivity concluded that working in an institution that is highly conducive to research strongly predicts faculty members’ research productivity.27 This finding was later confirmed by Bland et al., who also found other organizational culture factors (e.g., existence of a university mission on grants) and several other factors (i.e., coaching faculty in identifying potential sponsors, graduate student assistance) that distinguish units that tend to engage in grant-related activities versus those that don’t.28 Schweitzer’s research, contending that the devotion to doing research is not likely to bear fruit unless the organization’s culture embraces a research commitment, is also consistent with these findings.29

sec.title: Gaps in literature on faculty external grant activities in J/MC and HC
sec.p: Previous research is helpful in explaining how external grant productivity has been conceptualized and has accounted for it in terms of organizational attributes and organizational culture. This study capitalizes on five gaps in the meager research about the J/MC and HC disciplines to facilitate a more robust understanding of the norms and context within which external grant productivity transpires:

list-item.p: It remains unclear how much the external grant funds a communication unit’s faculty generates are associated with the degree of research support and research organizational culture present in the communication unit and host university. Illuminating these relationships may provide valuable clues toward generating precious external dollars.

Earlier research has not examined how the communication unit disciplinary emphasis (i.e., J/MC, J/MC and HC, HC) varies with the degree of research support faculty receive, the pressure or commitment to seek external funding, or the amount of external funding acquired, nor has it examined how these three variables are linked to existence of a graduate program in a communication unit.30 Doing so might help to establish what disciplinary or organizational emphases are more amenable to external grant activity success.

Most earlier research has not tested for Carnegie classification differences, therefore eschewing variations within doctoral, master’s, and baccalaureate campuses.31 Although Morton and Beard used the 1994 Carnegie classification, more recent versions exist.32 The 2005 Carnegie classification (the one used in this study) is an improvement of previous editions in terms of funding measures beyond federal sources.33 Analysis of how such classification differences relate to grant activity might help to establish how the degree of research emphasis in a program matters to grant activity success.

Although the number of faculty, number of students per communication unit, and number of students per university impinge on faculty research productivity,34 it remains unclear how they are related to the degree of research support faculty receive, the pressure or commitment to seek external funding, or the amount of external funding acquired. Determining whether institution or communication faculty size matters may have important implications for what organizational characteristics are better suited for research grant activity.

Little research has examined the attitudes of administrators in communication units regarding whether there is increased pressure to find external funding since the economic downturn. While that would seem to be self-evident, it is worth exploring because there may be similar relationships to the increased push for outside funding and the type of institution that houses the communication unit.

sec.p: Therefore, the following two hypotheses and several research questions are pertinent:

list-item.p: H1: The amount of research support provided at the unit and university level (independent variable) will be positively correlated with the amount of external grant money a communication unit’s faculty brings in (dependent variable).

H2: The perceived level of emphasis the unit and/or university places on external funding (independent variable) will be positively correlated with the amount of external grant money a communication unit’s faculty brings in (dependent variable).

sec.title: Research Questions

list-item.p: RQ1: Does the amount of research support provided to communication faculty vary depending on a set of seven independent variables?
RQ2: Does the degree to which the communication unit and the university are committed to seeking outside funding vary depending on a set of seven independent variables?
RQ3: Does the amount of external grant money a communication unit’s faculty brings in vary depending on a set of seven independent variables?

sec.p: The seven independent variables are the following:

list-item.p: Whether the program emphasizes mass communication, HC, or both
What type (if any) of graduate program it has
The size of its faculty
The percentage of faculty expected to conduct research
The research classification of its university
The size of the university
The size of the Communication Unit
RQ4: To what degree do respondents perceive that the pressure to receive external funding has increased in recent years?
RQ5: To what degree do respondents perceive that their university is providing the communication unit less support than other academic units?

sec.title: Method
sec.p: This study utilized a national Web survey (N = 136) of communication programs. The original sampling frame was a list of 330 programs obtained by downloading a compiled list of programs posted on the National Communication Association home page, a resource meant to be a complete list of all “communication” programs, which is therefore more likely to capture both human and mass communication programs than others such as an Association for Education in Journalism and Mass Communication program listing (although the list of J/MC programs surveyed each year by the Grady College of Journalism & Mass Communication, University of Georgia, numbers about 475). Program heads were contacted via email and asked to either complete the survey themselves or delegate the task to the person in the academic unit best able to answer questions about external funding of research. The response rate was 39 percent, including a sample representative of a broad cross section of programs.

Slightly more than 38 percent of respondents said their program was evenly split between HC and mass communication. Close to 35 percent reported that their program mostly or entirely focused on HC. A little more than 26 percent reported that their program mostly or entirely focused on mass communication.

Roughly one in five respondents (20 percent) reported that their program included a doctoral program. Another 42 percent reported having at least one master’s program. In terms of faculty size, the programs were relatively evenly split among those with ten or fewer, eleven to twenty, and more than twenty faculty members. More than half the programs (56.5 percent) reported having fewer than five hundred students, and 13 percent reported having more than one thousand students.

sec.title: Dependent and Independent Variables
sec.p: Although a survey such as this can only hope to show association and not causation, we have chosen to use the phrases “independent variable” and “dependent variable” in cases where a logical time order would seem to exist. There may be other mediating variables, such as the degree to which a program emphasizes professional tracks and/or teaching rather than research and thus eschews focusing on research grant activities. It is also possible that a faculty member may be a professional or clinical professor who is not expected to compete for grants or may be a tenured professor who does not prioritize bringing in grants.

However, we do mean to suggest that one variable likely precedes the other. For example, when we ask the research question “Does the amount of research support vary depending on what type of (if any) graduate program it has?” we do not mean to say that the graduate program automatically leads to increased research support. Rather, we mean to say that it is logical to assume for this study that the more graduate work being done in a unit, the more likely those graduate students are to help faculty with research, and therefore provide (and need) more research support.

sec.title: Dependent Variables
sec.p: This study has three measures that primarily serve as dependent variables: (1) research support for faculty seeking external funding, (2) pressure placed on faculty to seek external funding, and (3) the total amount of external funding a communication unit received in the previous year.

Research support for faculty seeking external funding was measured using a twelve-item scale (see Table 1). For each item, the respondent could check a box to indicate if the communication unit provided a specific support, such as internal grants or release time. The process was repeated so the same questions could be answered about university support. Boxes left blank were coded as zero. Boxes that were checked were coded as a 1. The answers from both unit and institution questions were then combined into a twenty-four-item additive scale. While the highest possible score on this scale was 24, the actual scores ranged from 0 to 20, with a mean of 6.4 and a standard deviation of 4.7.

caption.p: Percentage for Support Variables by Communication Program and University

tr.td: Release time to use grant funds for research

sec.p: Pressure placed on seeking external funding was measured in the same manner, asking first about the respondent’s unit, then following with the same items, focused on the respondent’s institution, as follows: encouraging outside funding of research, outside funding important in evaluation of faculty, a strong culture of grant-funded research/projects, little support in procuring it and/or managing external funding (reverse coded), view of outside funding of research important for a unit’s survival, historical culture of seeking outside funding for research. Possible answers were strongly disagree, disagree, neither agree nor disagree, agree, and strongly agree. The twelve items (mentioned in Table 1) were combined for an index with a Cronbach’s alpha of .83. The average on the 5-point Likert-type scale was 2.9 (range = 1–5), with a standard deviation of 0.74.

The total amount of external funding a communication unit received in the previous year was measured by asking respondents to report how much external research funding their unit generated that year; multiple-year grants were averaged for a per-year basis. The average was $42,797, with a standard deviation of $150,731.

sec.title: Independent Variables
sec.p: A total of nine independent variables were employed for this study. They included a common set of seven variables that, as mentioned earlier, were applied to RQ1, RQ2, and RQ3:

list-item.p: The communication discipline a program emphasized was operationalized with a question requiring respondents to choose from exclusively, mostly, or equal amounts of either mass or human (e.g., interpersonal or organizational) communication. The first two choices were collapsed and the last two choices were collapsed, so the three categories were all or mostly mass communication, equal amounts mass communication and HC, all or mostly HC.

Type of graduate program (if any) offered was measured in terms of the six options respondents were asked to choose from, including no; “sort of”: it’s in combination with another program on campus; yes, one master’s degree program only; yes, more than one master’s degree; yes, master’s and doctoral degree; yes, but a doctoral degree only. The first two choices were collapsed together, the third and fourth choices were combined, and the final two choices were integrated. The three resulting categories were no graduate program, a master’s program only, and a doctoral program.

Size of faculty was operationalized in terms of a question asking respondents how many full-time communication faculty were within their unit. Responses determined the following three categories: one to ten faculty, eleven to twenty faculty, and twenty-one or more faculty members.

The percentage of faculty expected to do research was assessed by asking respondents to state how many of the full-time faculty were expected to do research. Responses determined the following categories: 0–50 percent, 51–75 percent, and 76–100 percent.

Research classification of university was operationalized using the 2005 Carnegie Foundation’s classifications to create eleven exclusive options, including very high research activity (RU/VH); high research activity (RU/H); doctoral research university (DRU); larger master’s programs (L); medium master’s programs (M); smaller master’s programs (S); baccalaureate colleges–arts & sciences (Bac/A&S); baccalaureate colleges–diverse fields (Bac/Diverse); baccalaureate/associate’s colleges (Bac/Assoc); don’t know, but I wish to provide my institution name; and don’t know, but I do NOT wish to provide my institution name. The three categories of master’s program were collapsed into a single category, as were the three categories for bachelor’s programs. Those who selected “don’t know, but I do NOT wish to provide my institution name” were excluded from the analyses including this variable.

Size of the university was measured by asking respondents to approximate how large their institution was (keeping in mind their specific campus location, not the system of institutions in their state/city). Responses determined the following three categories: < 10,000, 10,001–20,000, > 20,000.

Number of students in the communication program was operationalized by asking. respondents to approximate how many students were in their communication unit. Responses determined the following three categories: < 500, 501–1,000, > 1,000.

sec.p: All dependent variables (described earlier) were measured at the interval or ratio level, while independent variables were measured at the nominal or ordinal level. As such, a series of correlations were run (after standardizing the variables) to test the hypotheses, whereas a series of one-way ANOVAs were run to test the association between each independent variable and each dependent variable for RQ1 through RQ7.

The eighth independent variable concerned perceived increase in pressure to land external funding in recent years. Respondents were asked to express their level of agreement on a 5-point Likert-type scale (strongly disagree to strongly agree) with a pair of questions: “Our unit has begun to emphasize external funding of research much more in the last two years than in the past” and “Our institution has begun to emphasize external funding of research much more in the last two years than in the past.”

The ninth independent variable focused on the degree to which respondents perceived their university. Respondents were asked to express their level of agreement on a 5-point Likert-type scale (strongly disagree to strongly agree) with the following statement: “Our institution helps other units procure outside funding more than it helps communication.”

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Nearly 62 percent of respondents reported that in the past fiscal year the communication unit had brought in no external funding, and another 22 percent reported bringing in less than $25,000. Just less than 3 percent reported bringing in $500,000 or more. Respondents reported that on average less than 25 percent of the research in their academic unit was funded, including internal grants.

sec.title: Research Support for Faculty Seeking External Funding
sec.p: Table 2 summarizes the results of several ANOVAs in response to RQ1, which examined different organizational factors and characteristics that account for the amount of research support to faculty. While no significant difference was found among programs that emphasized mass communication, HC, or equal emphasis on both, programs that offered graduate degrees provided significantly more support to faculty than did those without graduate programs (p < .01). Yet there was no significant difference between programs that offered doctoral programs and those with a master’s program but no terminal degree offering.

sec.p: A significant difference was also identified (p < .001) between programs with more than twenty faculty members in terms of offering faculty greater support than did smaller programs. There was no significant difference in the level of support that programs with ten or fewer faculty offered in comparison to programs with eleven to twenty faculty members.

In addition, programs where half or fewer of the faculty conduct research provide significantly less support (p < .01) than do programs where the majority of faculty are expected to do research. There was no difference in support between programs where 50 to 75 percent of faculty conduct research and programs where more than three-quarters of faculty conduct research.

Although there was a significant difference (p < .001) in the research support received by communication faculty with respect to Carnegie classification of the university, it existed only between the highest (RU/VH) and lowest ranked programs (Bac). There was also a significant trend (p < .001) toward programs at larger universities offering more research support than those at small or midsized universities. Moreover, programs with fewer than five hundred students offered faculty significantly less resources than larger programs. However, there was no difference between programs with five hundred to one thousand students and those with more than one thousand students.

In addition to the results referenced above in Table 2, data in response to RQ5 show that respondents perceived that their university is providing the communication unit less support than other academic units. More than 60 percent of respondents expressed agreement with that idea.

sec.title: Pressure Placed on Seeking External Funding
sec.p: Table 3 provides an overview of results from a series of ANOVAs regarding RQ2, which investigated several organizational factors and characteristics that explain the pressure on communication faculty to seek external grants. Whether a program emphasizes mass communication, HC, or both made no significant difference in terms of the level of pressure described. But respondents in programs with doctoral programs identified more pressure than did those with only master’s programs or no graduate program at all (p < .001). There was no difference between bachelor’s programs and master’s programs.

sec.p: Also, the larger the faculty, the greater the perceived pressure described (p < .001). Respondents on faculties with more than twenty people reported more pressure than those on faculties of ten or fewer or on faculties of eleven to twenty people. There was no significant difference between small and midsized faculties.

Moreover, pressure increased with the percentage of faculty expected to conduct research (p < .05), but the difference was significant only when comparing faculties with less than half the people doing research to those with at least three-quarters of faculty conducting research. Furthermore, programs whose universities were classified as “very high research” (RU/VH) exerted significantly more pressure than did programs of any other classification. Although there was a general trend toward more pressure with a higher classification, “large master’s” (L) programs bucked the trend by offering the second highest level of pressure despite being the fourth highest classification.

Also, results show that the larger the university, the higher the level of the pressure reported (p < .001). Universities with fewer than 10,000 students exerted less pressure than schools with 10,000 to 20,000 students, which in turn exerted less pressure than schools with more than 20,000 students.

Similarly, the general trend was that the larger the program, the more the perceived pressure (p < .001). Although respondents at programs with fewer than 500 students reported less pressure than respondents at programs with either 500 to 1,000 students or 1,000-plus students, there was no significant difference between midsized (500–1,000) and larger (more than 1,000) programs.

Beyond the ANOVA results depicted in Table 3 mentioned above, results in response to RQ4 indicate that nearly 43 percent of respondents expressed agreement with the idea that their academic unit was placing greater emphasis on receiving external funding than it had two years ago. More than half of the respondents expressed agreement with the idea that their university had begun placing more emphasis on external funding in recent years.

sec.title: Total Amount of External Funding Received by a Communication Unit
sec.p: Table 4 sketches results from several ANOVAs in response to RQ3, which examined how a list of organizational factors and characteristics account for the amount of external grant funding generated by communication faculty. No significant difference was found regarding whether the amount of external grant money brought in varies with a program’s emphasis on mass communication, HC, or both disciplines. However, communication units with doctoral programs brought in significantly more money (p < .001) than did units with either a master’s only program or no graduate program. There was no significant difference between undergraduate programs and those with a master’s degree. Doctoral programs brought in six figures on average ($143,914), compared to the low five figures for other programs.

sec.p: Also, larger programs brought in significantly more (p < .01) money than did smaller programs. Programs with more than twenty faculty members brought in an average of $114,046, compared to $23,756 for programs with eleven to twenty faculty and $5,562 for programs with ten or fewer faculty members. There was no significant difference between small (ten or fewer faculty members) and midsized (eleven to twenty faculty members) programs.

In addition, there were no significant differences in terms of whether the amount of external grant money a communication unit’s faculty gathers varies with the percentage of faculty expected to conduct research. But findings indicate that programs at “very high” (RU/VH) research institutions bring in significantly more (p < .01) than most other programs, yet the differences weren’t significant when comparing RU/VH institutions with high research (RU/H) and doctoral research institutions (DRU). Although communication units in RU/H and DRU institutions did not bring in significantly less external revenue than RU/VH programs, neither did they bring in significantly more external revenue than programs from lower categories.

Furthermore, programs at universities with more than 20,000 students brought in significantly (p < .05) more external funding than programs with fewer than 10,000 students. There were no significant differences among other groups. Communication unit programs with fewer than 500 students brought in significantly less (p < .05) than programs with more than 1,000 students. There were no significant differences among other categories.

In response to H1, the amount of grant money brought in positively correlated with the amount of support provided by the individual unit as well as the university (r = .3, p < .001). Similarly, regarding H2, the amount of grant money brought in positively correlated with the level of emphasis the unit and university placed on external funding.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusion
sec.p: We employed a survey of communication programs around the country to examine the degree to which those programs are getting external funding for their faculty research and whether certain variables (such as size of program, level of research support, emphasis of program) were associated with the level of funding.

Although this study did not employ longitudinal data, it provides some evidence of many programs reporting greater emphasis by the university and their own communication unit than ever to bring in external funding, yet very few have been successful to date. More than half of respondents report that their university has increased pressure to land grants, but fewer than four in ten communication programs reported bringing in even a single grant in the previous year. Results of the present study suggest that the rate of securing grants in the communication disciplines may have dropped well below the mark identified by previous research.35

Although some differences between this study and previous research may make a comparison difficult (e.g., previous research included only ACEJMC accredited programs; this study was more comprehensive), this does not alter the finding in this study that a large majority of communication units did not report any external grant acquisition. Moreover, the majority of those that did land a grant brought in less than $25,000.

We went beyond earlier research by investigating the relationship between pressure to generate external funding and acquisition of external funding.36 A case can be made that expectations for communication programs to generate external funding are growing faster than the support services to get that funding. As mentioned earlier, on a 24-point additive scale of support services, the mean score was 6.4, which is just barely above the first quartile or 25 percent. In addition, as reported earlier, more than 60 percent of respondents agreed with the notion that other programs on campus receive more support than the communication program. These results are consistent with previous research that suggested that although administrators of communication units reported some institutional support for grant-related activities (e.g., existence of a campus-sponsored research programs office),37 they were either neutral or dissatisfied with the level of support given to their units’ external grant activities (e.g., a streamlined “recognition and reward system” for grant winners or showing faculty how to get sponsors).

One goal of this project was to identify those variables that predict success in landing grants. In a nutshell, the finding regarding the most successful communication programs in terms of bringing in research funding resonates with earlier research’s determination that programs on doctoral campuses were overwhelmingly more likely to engage in external grant activities compared to those housed in either master’s or baccalaureate campuses.38

On the other hand, this study failed to find any significant difference regarding whether a program focuses on mass communication, HC, or both, nor did the study find any significant difference in terms of what percentage of faculty members are expected to do research, which suggests that doing research or getting published and getting external grants are not necessarily isomorphic, as has been proposed by some researchers.39

Therefore, as some prominent U.S. journalism schools (e.g., University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, University of Missouri at Columbia, Northwestern University) have demonstrated, if landing grant money is the goal, it may not be necessary to have a faculty full of researchers. Although additional research is required to reach a firmer conclusion, it seems likely that the best strategy is to have a mixture of faculty members with different skill sets and marching orders. For example, instructors who can teach a large number of courses can free up time for research-oriented faculty on reduced loads to go after grants. However, it should be noted that programs with more than twenty faculty members are significantly more successful than are smaller programs. Previous research suggests that faculty size is important for a unit’s capacity to accomplish its diverse professional goals in the academy.40 It is likely that smaller programs simply do not have the luxury of giving faculty members the release time they need to successfully compete for grants.

Although the level of support offered was correlated with funding success, the correlation was smaller than the correlation between pressure and success. While a support system is clearly important, it may well be that establishing a culture where externally funding success is seen as valuable may be even more crucial.

Communication programs at universities with the highest Carnegie classification brought significantly more external funding, even though the gaps in support and pressure are far less robust when making comparisons across groups. Even if this study’s findings cannot be directly compared with findings from earlier research because of the different versions of the Carnegie classification systems involved,41 this study identified a discernible pattern of programs with the highest classification (i.e., RU/VH) securing significantly more external funding than programs in most of the remaining classifications. But like previous research, this study found few robust differences between the different categories within classifications and between classifications.42

Although programs in the RU/VH classification do appear to have more resources and pressure, there would seem to be more to the story. The missing link may be the greater access faculty in these programs have to researchers in other disciplines on their campus who are successful in landing grants. Indeed, research that was noted earlier found that a major distinguishing factor of communication programs that are active in grant-related research is the emphasis on networking among peers who share similar grant and research interests.43

Thus, no university’s Carnegie classification comes down to the success or failure of its communication program. Research in medicine and the hard sciences typically accounts for a great deal of a university’s external research funding. Many grants in the hard sciences have a communication component. Communication researchers who have the ability to partner with hard scientists on their campus who already have a track record of landing external funding would appear to be at a decided advantage. But even within the communication disciplines, growing areas such as health communication have provided notable grant opportunities. This has led to the mushrooming of health communication components in a number of J/MC programs as well as HC programs.

Although this study has extended explication of the norms of external funding in the communication disciplines, future research can capitalize on the findings herein by directly tapping the perceptions of faculty rather than just the views of administrators and also complementing quantitative data with qualitative data such as what focus groups of faculty can provide. Furthermore, it would be helpful to utilize a sample that reflects a more balanced distribution of predominantly J/MC programs versus predominantly HC programs to minimize sampling bias. Comparing data obtained from self-report studies such as this one to data generated from archival sources could also generate additional insights.

These limitations notwithstanding, this study not only is a solid update of previous studies on this important subject but also, as discussed above, has illuminated challenges (e.g., support of faculty that is out of sync with the pressure to seek grants) as well as some recipes for success (e.g., having a doctoral communication program and a large faculty of at least twenty). Thus, administrators and communication faculty can operate from a more informed perspective toward greater external grant achievement.
